articles.headline: A Daunting Path to Prosperity
articles.snippet: Bureaucracy and politics often overwhelm economics in Italy, where growth is sorely needed.
articles.abstract: Bureaucracy and politics often overwhelm economics in Italy, where growth is sorely needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: PISA, Italy — Six years ago, the Swedish retail giant Ikea planned a 60-million-euro megastore just a few miles from where the Tower of Pisa leans into the earth. Backers said the huge construction project, new roads and wave of shoppers would bring hundreds of sorely needed jobs to this bucolic corner of Tuscany.

articles.headline: Lehman Case Hints at Need to Stiffen Audit Rules
articles.snippet: A judge threw out a claim against Ernst & Young, whose audit certified that Lehman had followed accepted accounting principles.
articles.abstract: A judge threw out a claim against Ernst & Young, whose audit certified that Lehman had followed accepted accounting principles.
articles.lead_paragraph: The company misled investors and its officers and directors may be held liable. But the company’s auditor seems likely to escape any responsibility for an audit that wrongly concluded the company’s financial statements were completely proper.

articles.headline: In Baring Facts of Train Crash, Blogs Erode China Censorship
articles.snippet: China’s major Twitter-like microblogs posted an astounding 26 million messages on the crash, a potent amalgam of contempt, suspicion and shoe-leather journalism.
articles.abstract: China’s major Twitter-like microblogs posted an astounding 26 million messages on the crash, a potent amalgam of contempt, suspicion and shoe-leather journalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — “After all the wind and storm, what’s going on with the high-speed train?” read the prophetic message posted last Saturday evening on the Chinese microblog Sina Weibo. “It’s crawling slower than a snail. I hope nothing happens to it.”
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Drug App Comes Free, Ads Included
articles.snippet: Epocrates has won over nearly half of the nation’s doctors with its smartphone app. But “free” comes with a price.
articles.abstract: Epocrates has won over nearly half of the nation’s doctors with its smartphone app. But “free” comes with a price.
articles.lead_paragraph: Epocrates has won over nearly half of the nation’s doctors for its free smartphone apps that lets them look up information on drug dosing, interactions and insurance coverage while seeing a patient.

articles.headline: A Recovery That Repeats Its Painful Precedents
articles.snippet: Like recoveries from other recessions that stemmed from financial crises, this one seems doomed to be slow and painful.
articles.abstract: Like recoveries from other recessions that stemmed from financial crises, this one seems doomed to be slow and painful.

articles.headline: Just Before Deadline, County in Alabama Delays Bankruptcy Move
articles.snippet: Commissioners are taking seven days to study a proposal that would reduce the total amount owed, bring down the county’s interest rate and avert bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: Commissioners are taking seven days to study a proposal that would reduce the total amount owed, bring down the county’s interest rate and avert bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: There may still be a way out for Jefferson County, the Alabama county being crushed by its debt.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: Japanese, in Shortage, Willingly Ration Watts
articles.snippet: Since the nuclear disaster, Japan has pushed to conserve electricity, even as it tries to revive its economy.
articles.abstract: Since the nuclear disaster, Japan has pushed to conserve electricity, even as it tries to revive its economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — With Japan suffering from electricity shortages this summer, Michio Kuniyuki has stepped up his conservation patrols of Rikkyo University.

articles.headline: Judge’s Ruling in Madoff Case Could Reduce Money for Victims
articles.snippet: The ruling could pare billions of dollars from the sum that may ultimately be recovered for victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: The ruling could pare billions of dollars from the sum that may ultimately be recovered for victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled on Thursday that the bankruptcy trustee trying to recover billions for those who lost money in Bernard L. Madoff’s enormous Ponzi scheme did not have the right to sue banks and other third parties on behalf of the victims.

articles.headline: Carmakers Back Strict New Rules for Gas Mileage
articles.snippet: A hike in government fuel rules to 54.5 miles per gallon by 2025 is being meekly accepted by the car industry.
articles.abstract: A hike in government fuel rules to 54.5 miles per gallon by 2025 is being meekly accepted by the car industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Four years ago, the American auto industry was so opposed to higher fuel economy standards that executives of Detroit camped out in Washington in an unsuccessful bid to undercut them.

articles.headline: Study Faults Approval Process for Medical Devices
articles.snippet: A top scientific group said the system that examines the safety of devices like artificial hips should be replaced.
articles.abstract: A top scientific group said the system that examines the safety of devices like artificial hips should be replaced.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government’s system for regulating many medical devices like artificial hips should be abandoned and replaced because it fails to examine their safety and effectiveness before sale, according to a report released Friday by one of the nation’s top scientific groups.

articles.headline: New Data Shows Sharp Slowdown in Growth Rate
articles.snippet: The 1.3 percent annual rate of growth for the U.S. economy was well below expectations, and revised data showed that the recession was worse than initially estimated.
articles.abstract: The 1.3 percent annual rate of growth for the U.S. economy was well below expectations, and revised data showed that the recession was worse than initially estimated.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The economy slowed to a snail’s pace in the first half of 2011, underscoring a growing risk that the recovery itself may hang in the balance with budget and debt decisions in Washington.

articles.headline: Senate Quickly Kills Boehner Debt Bill
articles.snippet: House Republicans muscled through a revised plan, but it was quickly dispatched by Senate Democrats, setting the stage for an uncertain 72 hours as the deadline approaches.
articles.abstract: House Republicans muscled through a revised plan, but it was quickly dispatched by Senate Democrats, setting the stage for an uncertain 72 hours as the deadline approaches.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a 24-hour delay and concessions to conservatives, the House on Friday narrowly approved a Republican fiscal plan that the Senate quickly rejected in a standoff over the federal debt ceiling that was keeping the government on a path to potential default.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Robert Pear
